Summary: Remote debug does not start
Description:
***What steps will reproduce the issue?***

1. Choosing a CMake config which is related to debug remote platform (in my case, a Raspberry Pi 5 8Gb)

2. Starting a debug session with the 'bug' button

***What is the expected result?***

Debug session starts and program starts too

***What happens instead?***

Debug window opens, console contain nothing, then after a while, I get that:

> Command timed out
>
> Process finished with exit code 0

***What OS and IDE versions are used?** (Help or App menu \| About)*

> CLion 2024.3 EAP
>
> Build #CL-243.19420.28, built on October 9, 2024
>
> Licensed to CLion EAP user: Patrice Espie
>
> Expiration date: November 8, 2024
>
> Runtime version: 21.0.4+8-b620.4 amd64 (JCEF 122.1.9)
>
> VM: OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM by JetBrains s.r.o.
>
> Toolkit: sun.awt.X11.XToolkit
>
> Linux 6.2.0-26-generic
>
> .NET Core v8.0.4 x64 (Server GC)
>
> GC: G1 Young Generation, G1 Concurrent GC, G1 Old Generation
>
> Memory: 4000M
>
> Cores: 8
>
> Registry:
>
>   actionSystem.update.actions.warn.dataRules.on.edt=false
>
>   debugger.attach.dialog.enabled=true
>
>   run.processes.with.pty=TRUE
>
>   ide.experimental.ui=true
>
>   ide.slow.operations.assertion=false
>
>   cache.folding.model.on.disk=false
>
>   i18n.locale=
>
> Non-Bundled Plugins:
>
>   com.intellij.ml.llm (243.19420.21)
>
> Current Desktop: ubuntu:GNOME

*Please attach the [IDE logs](https://intellij-support.jetbrains.com/hc/en-us/articles/207241085) to the issue. In case of performance issues, please also [attach the relevant snapshots](https://intellij-support.jetbrains.com/hc/en-us/articles/207241235).*
*Code samples, screenshots, or screencasts illustrating the problem are always appreciated.*

Obviously, the application works locally, in a debug session or a launch, and works remotely if launched in CLion.
In a terminal, I was also able to issue the following command:

Summary: Angular Wrap HTML Block in Control Flow Blocks
Description:
It would be nice to have something like 'surround with emmet' to surround HTML blocks with a certain element, to have something similar for angular's control flow blocks.

Enabling developers with just a few keystrokes to add an @defer around an entire block would be quite convenient and greatly improve the ergonomy!

Summary: Compose resources: fix navigation in case of common resources used in single target projects
Description:
STR: 
- create project from https://kmp.jetbrains.com/ with only one target selected, e.g. Android
- open project in Fleet and open `composeApp/src/androidMain/../App.kt`
- try to navigate to `Res.drawable.compose_multiplatform`

ER: navigate to `compose_multiplatform.xml`
AR: navigates to internal representation

BSP plugin should only depend optionally on language plugins
Description:
To be compatible with non-IDEA IDEs, e.g. PyCharm and GoLand, the BSP (and Bazel) plugin can not depend on any language plugin obligatorily.

Currently we depend on the Java, Kotlin, Scala and Python plugins, but only the Python plugin is optional. 
- The Java plugin is tightly coupled with the project model code and may require extensive refactoring to be optional
- The Kotlin plugin is less tightly coupled, but may still require some work
- The Scala plugin is only coupled through a mutual dependency on the coursier library

Summary: Create file from snippet - add the file to the directory outlined in the chat
Description:
## **Scenario**

While working in the AI chat with AI Assistant, it will suggest to create files in specific locations/directories of the project.
It would be beneficial if we could create the file via 'create file from snippet' option in the directory that was proposed by the AI.


**Actual result:**
When we use the 'create file from snippet' option, the file is always created in the currently selected project directory.
The location suggested in the AI chat is not respected.

**Desirable result:**
While sometimes it is handy to create file in the currently selected directory, it could be also useful to use the path suggested in the AI chat.
Maybe this could be a configurable behavior.

![](image.png){width=80%}

## **Workaround**
Select the needed directory in the project view and the file will be created there.

Strange completion content
Description:
Maybe it is just me, but I find this behavior very strange.

If I have the code

```
public static void main(String[] args) {
    for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
    
    }
}
```

and do AI inline completion in the `for`\-loop, the suggestion for whatever reason is `System.out.println("Hello, World!");`.

But what I consider really strange is, if I type an `S` and do the completion again, I would have expected the same suggestion, but now it turned to `System.out.println(i);`.

And even more strange, if I add a `y` after the `S`, the completion becomes `SySystem.out.println(i);` (yes, `SySy`, that is not a typo here).

With `System` typed, no completion at all happens. (Same after `System.out` and `System.out.println`)

With `System.` typed, the completion becomes `System.println("Hello World");` (yes, without `.out`)

With `System.out.prn` (which is a typo of course), the completion becomes `System.out.prnln("Hello World!");`, worsening the typo.

Description:

Add a single file and complete after `=` ```java class Scratch { public static void main(String[] args) { String value1 = "qwe"; String value2 = } } ``` ![](image.png){width=50%} Note, it's relevant to any language. Example with typescript: ```ts type Color = "red" | "green" | "blue" var color: Color = ``` ![](image1.png){width=50%} ------------- I've checked it in IntelliJ IDEA 2024.1.2 RC and a freshly installed WebStorm 2024.1.3 I assume it's a common platform issue actual to all IDEs. Summary: AI completion issue
Description:
Typing the last "y" in the value produces the following suggestion, which I find incorrect.

Summary: Slow operations are prohibited on EDT. See SlowOperations.assertSlowOperationsAreAllowed javadoc.
Slow operations are prohibited on EDT. See SlowOperations.assertSlowOperationsAreAllowed javadoc.
Autocomplete: syntax highlighting of suggested snippets
Description:
Syntax highlighting is the most essential thing an IDE is expected to provide.

However, there's no syntax highlighting in snippet completion:
![](image.png){width=50%}

Displaying everything in grey color is OK for a single identifier, or maybe even a single line, however, it's not ideal when it comes to larger snippets of code.

Users need to read and comprehend the code to understand whether it's a suitable option, and it would be significantly easier to do with syntax highlighting.

Obviously, we should still distinguish the suggested code from the existing code somehow - we may experiment with using brightness/alpha, background, or border.

Summary: Unhandled coroutine throwable
Cannot create a range marker from range “(15,979 - 15,979)” because it falls outside of the document range “(0 - 15,967)”
Invalid "Field may have a Lombok setter" warning on boolean setter "setIs…" for field "is…"
Description:
***What steps will reproduce the issue?***
Given following code:

```
private boolean isUri;

public void setIsUri(boolean isUri) { this.isUri = isUri; }
```

***What happens?***

An inspection warning is issued on the setter method, suggesting "Field may have a Lombok setter". However, applying the autofix to use a lombok `@Setter` will generate `setUri(boolean)` instead.

***What is the expected result?***

No inspection warning should be offered on above setter method. 

However, it should indeed be offered on a setter `public void setUri(boolean isUri) { this.isUri = isUri; }` –  which it isn't.

Invalid breakpoints shouldn't break the debugger
Description:
***What steps will reproduce the issue?***
1\. Write simple test:

```
it('should work with debugger', () => {
    expect(true).toEqual(true);
})
```

2\. Set a breakpoint at line 2: expect(true).toEqual(true).

3\. Start debugger (I used context menu on file: "debug example.test.js")

***What is the expected result?***

Debugger view starts and process is stopped at breakpoint.

***What happens instead?***

Jest debugger stops with error message:

```bash

For help, see: https://nodejs.org/en/docs/inspector
Debugger attached.
KEYBOARD_INTERRUPT: Script execution was interrupted by `SIGINT`

Process finished with exit code 130 (interrupted by signal 2: SIGINT)
```

Summary: Regular folder should have parent folder
Code Inspection Warning: Expected type 'Series', got 'bool' instead
Description:
# Steps to Reproduce

Consider the following Python code:

import pandas



df: pandas.DataFrame = pandas.DataFrame(

    data={

        "x": [1, 2, 3],

        "y": ["a", "b", "a"],

        "z": ["foo", "bar", "baz"]

    }

)



predicate1: pandas.Series = (df["x"] == 1) & (df["y"] == "a")

predicate2: pandas.Series = df["x"].eq(1) & df["y"].eq("a")



When you run Code Inspection, you get the following warning for the line where predicate1 is defined: "Expected type 'Series', got 'bool' instead. However, the line where predicate2 is defined does not generate a warning. Both lines yield exactly the same result which is a pandas.Series. However, PyCharm 2024.2.3 shows the warning while PyCharm 2022.2.3 does not.

# Expected Result

Code inspection should not show a warning since using the & operator on two Series yields a Series. Note that the expression df["x"] == 1 is a pandas.Series and so is the expression df["y"] == "a". See <https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/user_guide/boolean.html#> .

# Actual Result
